University of Leicester https://www2.le.ac.uk These are the search results for the query, showing results 1 to 15. Research Lecture: Astrobiology and the detection of life in our solar system https://www2.le.ac.uk/departments/interdisciplinary-science/public-events/research-lectures/zita-martins/research-lecture-astrobiology-and-the-detection-of-life-in-our-solar-system Astrobiology and the detection of life in our solar system

The origin of life on Earth is one of the biggest scientific questions waiting to be answered, with the most recent theories suggesting the presence of water and a continuous supply of prebiotic organic compounds as a requirement.

The first experimental analysis on the abiotic formation of the building blocks of life was performed in 1953 by Stanley Miller, who synthesised organic compounds using a spark discharge in a mixture of reduced gases. Although this was a ground breaking result, it was later showed that the atmospheric conditions used in this experiment did not correspond to the ones of our primitive planet.

As the Earth was heavily bombarded by comets, asteroids, meteorites and interplanetary dust particle (IDPs) 4.6 to 3.8 million years ago, the exogenous delivery of organic compounds is an alternative. In fact, carbonaceous meteorites have a rich organic inventory, and may have provided the first building blocks of life to the primitive Earth. As future space missions will investigate the possibility of past and/or present extra-terrestrial life, it is important to determine how life may have originated in other places of our solar system, and how to detect possible bio-signatures.

This talk will discuss how the study of meteorites, asteroids, comets and Mars soil analogues is used to investigate the origin of life on Earth and how to detect any possible signatures of extra-terrestrial life in our solar system.

Flyer for this event

\ufffd\ufffd

Dr Zita Martins

Dr Zita Martins is a Royal Society University\ufffd\ufffdResearch Fellow at Imperial College London. Her research interests include the detection of bio-signatures in space missions, and the possible contribution of meteorites and comets to the origin of life on Earth. Dr Zita Martins has an MSc in Chemistry from Instituto Superior T\ufffd\ufffdcnico (Portugal, 2003) and a PhD in Astrobiology from the University of Leiden (The Netherlands, 2007). She was an Invited Scientist at NASA Goddard in 2005 and 2006, and an Invited Professor at the University of Nice-Sophia Antipolis (France) in 2012. After her PhD, Dr Martins moved to Imperial College London as Post-Doc Research Associate, and since 2009 she has been a Royal Society University Research Fellow.

Dr Martins is a Co-Investigator in one European Space Agency (ESA-ELIPS) space mission experiment (OREOCube) which will be on-board the International Space Station, a member of two ESA Topical Teams (Future Astrobiology Experiments in Earth orbit and beyond, and Lunar Exploitation of local planetary materials), and a Committee member of the Astrobiology Society of Britain (ASB). She has been an invited speaker in several international conferences including the Gordon Research Conference and the COSPAR Conference. Dr Martins has an active involvement with public outreach activities, including several international media interviews, and public talks at museums and Science festivals. She was selected as one of the BBC's Expert Women, and she had the honour of having her portrait sketched for the Royal Society exhibit about great women in science.

]]> No publisher lr158 Biology Natural Sciences Biological Sciences Event Astronomy Astrophysics Biochemistry Event:Lecture Interdisciplinary science 2014-11-20T17:00:00Z Event University welcomes new President and Vice-Chancellor https://www2.le.ac.uk/news/blog/2014-archive-1/september/university-welcomes-new-president-and-vice-chancellor Professor Paul Boyle gives video interview upon taking office Today (1 October), the University welcomes Professor Paul Boyle FBA, FRSE as our new President and Vice-Chancellor.

Professor Boyle succeeds Professor Sir Robert Burgess who has retired after 15 years\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd distinguished service to the University.

Professor Paul Boyle was former Chief Executive of the Economic and Social Research Council and President of Science Europe.\ufffd\ufffd He was also International Champion of Research Councils UK with responsibility for international strategy on behalf of all seven Research Councils.

He is the ninth institutional head in the University\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds 90-year-plus history and its sixth Vice-Chancellor since the award of its Royal Charter in 1957.

In an interview for staff and students on our dedicated microsite, Professor Paul Boyle speaks of his delight at leading Leicester after serving as Chief Executive of the Economic and Social Research Council.
You can also find a biography, press release and welcome messages to staff and students (to be announced).

]]> No publisher pt91 Country House Biochemistry Psychology Medical and Social Care Education Cell Physiology and Pharmacology Vice-Chancellor Urban History Lifelong learning Medicine Computer Science History Economics Management Cancer Studies and Molecular Medicine Interdisciplinary science Politics Criminology Mathematics Engineering Chemistry Geography Victorian History of Art and Film Museum Studies Biological Sciences Genetics Magazine:Student English Physics and Astronomy Cardiovascular English local history Infection, Immunity and Inflammation Media and Communications Sociology Biology Modern Languages Law Health Sciences Labour Market Studies Geology Education Archaeology American Studies 2014-09-30T19:00:00Z Blog Entry New report suggests freshers struggle to remember basic A-level concepts https://www2.le.ac.uk/news/blog/2014-archive-1/june/new-report-suggests-freshers-struggle-to-remember-basic-a-level-concepts Professor Jon Scott involved in developing and implementing national study A new report shows that even grade-A students can only remember 40 per cent of their A-Level syllabus by the first week of term at university.

Researchers tested nearly 600 students in their first week of term at five universities.

It is hoped that the findings will assist the re-design of A-Levels to make them more relevant to higher education. The results could also prove useful for designing undergraduate courses which are more student-focused.

Academic Registrar at the University of Leicester Professor Jon Scott (pictured)\ufffd\ufffdsaid: \ufffd\ufffd\ufffdAt Leicester\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds School of Biological Sciences, we have been very committed to improving student retention and the student experience of transition into higher education. I have co-authored a number of papers in this area from both the academic and the social aspects of the student experience.

\ufffd\ufffd\ufffdThis study fitted directly into this work and I was very pleased to be involved in the development and implementation of the study. Looking ahead, we will be able to use the results to re-evaluate our approach to first year teaching.\ufffd\ufffd In addition, we want to engage in the current debate about the design of A levels so that the approach can be more tailored for the purpose of preparing students for higher education.

\ufffd\ufffd\ufffdThe work is ongoing and the team is on the process of preparing some more material for publication.\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd

\ufffd\ufffd\ufffdIndications of knowledge retention in the transition to Higher Education\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd is published in the journal Journal of Biological Education.

  • Press Release
]]> No publisher ap507 Magazine:Research Cell Physiology and Pharmacology Biological Sciences Magazine:Staff Magazine:Student 2014-06-25T10:04:21Z Blog Entry Student awarded 'summer studentship' by the Dr Hadwen Trust https://www2.le.ac.uk/news/blog/2014-archive-1/june/student-awarded-summer-studentship-by-the-dr-hadwen-trust Biomedical Science student Karishma Joshi wins prestigious award Biomedical Science student Karishma Joshi has been awarded a prestigious \ufffd\ufffd\ufffdSummer Studentship\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd by the Dr Hadwen Trust (DHT), the UK\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds leading non-animal medical research charity.

The DHT scheme enables undergraduate students to extend their studies over the summer by gaining practical laboratory experience.

Karishma\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds project involves research into tuberculosis (TB). TB in humans is a serious problem globally and is spread by the microbe Mycobacterium tuberculosis (Mtb) when people with an active infection cough. This research is focused on understanding the spread of infection, and aims to reduce the need for TB research to be conducted by using animals.

She\ufffd\ufffdsaid, \ufffd\ufffd\ufffdI was really excited when I found out that I was being awarded the grant from the Dr Hadwen Trust. I'm definitely considering a future in research and I feel that this award will allow me to gain an insight into what a future in research may entail.\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd

For more information about the Dr Hadwen Trust see here.

  • Press Release
]]> No publisher ap507 Magazine:Research Magazine:Student Magazine:Staff Infection, Immunity and Inflammation Biological Sciences 2014-06-23T15:26:26Z Blog Entry Staff and students invited to Summer Reunion Open Day 2014 https://www2.le.ac.uk/news/blog/2014-archive-1/june/local-community-invited-to-summer-reunion-open-day-2014 Exciting events for all the family to take place on Saturday 28 June Graduates, staff, students and their families and friends will be gathering at the University on Saturday 28 June for an exciting day of free lectures, tours, demonstrations and workshops \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd and to celebrate the leading research and teaching taking place at the institution.

The Summer Reunion Open Day 2014 will feature a variety of engaging activities and also celebrates the 25th anniversary of the School of Biological Sciences.

The event will give attendees the opportunity to hear from Professor Sir Robert Burgess, Vice-Chancellor of the University of Leicester, during what will be his last Summer Reunion as host before he steps down in September of this year.

The memorable day will conclude with the Leicester Alumni Dinner from 7:00pm in the Charles Wilson Building, 1st Floor restaurant.

The Summer Reunion Open Day 2014 takes place on Saturday 28 June at the University of Leicester.

To book your place and to view the complete programme of activities at the Open Day, click here.

  • Press Release
]]> No publisher ap507 Biological Sciences Magazine:Staff Chemistry Magazine:Student Genetics History Magazine:Research Alumni 2014-06-13T15:15:00Z Blog Entry Accreditation success for School of Biological Sciences https://www2.le.ac.uk/news/blog/2014-archive-1/april/the-school-of-biological-sciences-achieves-society-of-biology-accreditation Recognition provides external guarantee of academic excellence to students and to employers Biological Sciences students who complete an industrial placement year from 2014-15 on will now graduate with a Society of Biology accredited degree.

Accredited degrees provide an external guarantee of academic excellence to students and employers, and provide students with the skills and experiences needed to enter a successful career in the biosciences through practical research, up to date knowledge and defined experimental techniques.

A spokesperson for the Society of Biology,\ufffd\ufffd the UK learned society for biologists, said: "Degree accreditation by the Society of Biology recognises academic excellence in the biosciences, and highlights degrees that educate the research and development leaders and innovators of the future. The accreditation criteria require evidence that graduates from the programme meet defined sets of learning outcomes, including gaining a substantial period of research experience."

Eleven biological sciences degrees offered by the University will carry this accreditation, including BSc Biological Sciences, BSc medical Biochemistry, Bsc Medical Genetics and BSc Medical Microbiology.

For more information click here.

]]> No publisher ap507 Magazine:Staff Biological Sciences Magazine:Student 2014-04-30T14:05:00Z Blog Entry The School of Biological Sciences achieves Society of Biology accreditation https://www2.le.ac.uk/departments/biologicalsciences/news-and-events/biological-sciences-degrees-accredited-by-the-society-of-biology The School of Biological Sciences is delighted to be able to announce that the following degree programmes have been approved as accredited degrees by the Society of Biology:

BSc Biological Sciences (With A Year In Industry)
BSc Biological Sciences (Biochemistry) (With A Year In Industry)
BSc Biological Sciences (Genetics) (With A Year In Industry)
BSc Biological Sciences (Microbiology) (With A Year In Industry)
BSc Biological Sciences (Neuroscience) (With A Year In Industry)
BSc Biological Sciences (Physiology with Pharmacology) (With A Year In Industry)
BSc Biological Sciences (Zoology) (With A Year In Industry)
BSc Medical Biochemistry (With A Year In Industry)
BSc Medical Genetics (With A Year In Industry)
BSc Medical Microbiology (With A Year In Industry)
BSc Medical Physiology (With A Year In Industry)

Accredited degrees are those that meet the accreditation assessment criteria by:

  • Developing research-ready graduates by providing practical research experience
  • Focusing on academic excellence by teaching to most up-to-date knowledge and experimental techniques
  • Delivering a defined set of knowledge, skill, and abilities

University of Leicester Biological Sciences students who complete an industrial placement year from 2014-15 on will graduate with an accredited degree. According to the Society of Biology, the UK learned society for biologists, this means that:

"Degree accreditation by the Society of Biology recognises academic excellence in the biosciences, and highlights degrees that educate the research and development leaders and innovators of the future. The accreditation criteria require evidence that graduates from the programme meet defined sets of learning outcomes, including gaining a substantial period of research experience."

In other words, accreditation is an external guarantee of academic excellence to students and to employers and will serve as a valuable recruitment tool in an era of increasing competition for students. Degrees accredited by the Society have been shown to provide graduates with the skills and experience needed to enter a successful career in the biosciences.

Thanks to all those in the School of Biological Sciences who contributed to the success of this application.

]]> No publisher dg144 Biological Sciences 2014-04-15T13:25:00Z Blog Entry Examining student perceptions of learning outcomes https://www2.le.ac.uk/news/blog/2014-archive-1/april/examing-student-perceptions-of-learning-outcomes New paper published in Teaching in Higher Education by the Learning Outcomes Project The Learning Outcomes Project team has published a new paper\ufffd\ufffdin Teaching in Higher Education entitled \ufffd\ufffd\ufffdLearning about learning outcomes: the student perspective\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd, which is based on research conducted\ufffd\ufffdon students at the University concerning their perceptions about, and uses of, learning outcomes.

Despite an extensive literature on how to frame learning outcomes, to date limited attention has been given to understanding whether and how students actually use them. This study employed a questionnaire survey and focus groups with students in three disciplines at the University to explore students' perceptions and use of learning outcomes.

The findings suggest that the majority of students find learning outcomes useful and use them to support their studies in various ways. However, the data also indicate that some students struggle to understand from their learning outcomes the level of learning required to cover their topic area or to pass assessments.

Additionally, certain respondents reported that learning outcomes can restrict or overfragment their knowledge. Whilst many students wanted learning outcomes to remain a central part of their learning experience, the findings suggest further work is required to establish more effective use of learning outcomes as a learning resource.

The Learning Outcomes Project team are Dr Kerry Dobbins and Dr Bob Norman from the Department of Medical and Social Care Education, Professor Jon Scott from the School of Biological Sciences, and Dr Mark Rawlinson from the School of English.

]]> No publisher ap507 Magazine:Research Medical and Social Care Education Biological Sciences Magazine:Staff English Magazine:Student 2014-04-08T12:10:00Z Blog Entry Genomes of Richard III and his proven relative to be sequenced https://www2.le.ac.uk/news/blog/2014-archive-1/february/genomes-of-richard-iii-and-his-proven-relative-to-be-sequenced Richard III to be first ancient individual of known identity to have genome sequenced The genomes of King Richard III and one of his family\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds direct living descendants are to be sequenced in a project funded by the Wellcome Trust, the Leverhulme Trust and Professor Sir Alec Jeffreys, Emeritus Professor at the University of Leicester who discovered genetic fingerprinting. The project will be led by Dr Turi King (pictured)\ufffd\ufffdof the Department of Genetics at the University.

The aim is to shed new light on the ancestry and health of the last king of England to die in battle, and provide a complete archive of information that historians, scientists and the public will be able to access and use.

Dr Turi King and colleagues plan to sequence his genome and make it freely accessible as a resource to researchers wishing to analyse and interrogate its genetic information.

Richard III will be the first ancient individual of known identity to have his genome sequenced. This will be carried out in collaboration with Professor Michael Hofreiter at the University of Potsdam.

In addition to sequencing the remains of Richard III, Dr King and colleagues will also sequence one of his living relatives, Michael Ibsen. An initial analysis of the DNA of his mitochondria \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd the batteries that power the cells in our bodies \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd which is passed down the maternal line, confirmed the genealogical evidence that Ibsen and Richard III shared the same lineage.

This new project will allow researchers to look for any other segments of DNA that these distant relatives share.

  • The Dig for Richard III was led by the University of Leicester, working with Leicester City Council and in association with the Richard III Society. The originator of the Search project was Philippa Langley of the Richard III Society.
  • Press Release
  • Link to the University's iTunes collection about the Richard III search and discovery

Listen and watch Dr Turi King discussing her research below:

]]> No publisher ap507 Genetics Magazine:Research Magazine:Staff Health Sciences News Alumni Biology Archaeology ULAS Molecular Biology Richard III Ancient History Medical School Anthropology Biological Sciences Magazine:Student College:MedBioPsych 2014-02-11T18:00:00Z Blog Entry Student research to make polystyrene more recyclable https://www2.le.ac.uk/news/blog/2013/november/a-step-closer-to-making-polystyrene-easier-to-recycle Biological Sciences students clone bacterial genes involved in breaking down toluene, an environmental pollutant A team of\ufffd\ufffdBiological Sciences\ufffd\ufffdundergraduates\ufffd\ufffdhave isolated and cloned the DNA sequences responsible for degrading a chemical called toluene.\ufffd\ufffd

Having now isolated the genes,\ufffd\ufffdthey can modify them to degrade other oil-based chemicals. One of the students\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd targets is polystyrene (pictured, right), a plastic chemically related to toluene that is currently difficult to recycle, as it is hard to break down.

The team have made\ufffd\ufffdprogress towards ensuring that polystyrene can be more easily recycled\ufffd\ufffd- for which they have received financial support from the British Plastics Federation and Jablite / Styropack, a major UK polystyrene manufacturer.

The students carried out the research as part of the\ufffd\ufffdUniversity's 2013 entry to the iGEM (international Genetically Engineered Machine) research competition, which challenges students to synthesise novel organisms using a set of standard DNA parts.

The team presented the results of their summer research project in mid-October at the iGEM Competition European Jamboree, in Lyon France.

  • Press Release
]]> No publisher ap507 Magazine:Staff Biological Sciences Chemistry Magazine:Research Magazine:Business Magazine:Student 2013-11-20T09:55:00Z Blog Entry University expertise shapes national guidelines https://www2.le.ac.uk/news/blog/2013/july/university-expertise-shapes-national-guidelines Advice from University researchers aims to tackle obesity and incidence of diabetes University of Leicester expertise has contributed to national guidelines to tackle obesity. The National Institute for Health and Care Excellence (NICE) has set a lower body mass index (BMI) target for Asians in the country, bringing the UK in line with Indian and World Health Organisation recommendations.

Evidence of the work at the Diabetes Research Unit at the University of Leicester was given as a report to this NICE Guidance by Professor Kamlesh Khunti and Dr Danielle Morris. This work led by Professor Kamlesh Khunti and Professor Melanie Davies commenced around 12 years ago and has informed a number of national and international guidelines.

Until now, experts have said all UK adults should aim for a BMI of no more than 25 to be healthy.\ufffd\ufffd But NICE says that doesn't go far enough for certain ethnic groups and that Asian people should aim for a BMI lower than 23.\ufffd\ufffdAccording to the new guidelines, a 5ft 11in (1.8m) Asian man should weigh below 75kg and an Asian woman who is 5ft 3in (1.6m) should weigh less than 59kg.\ufffd\ufffdDiabetes UK added that it was good to move away from a "one size fits all" approach to BMI.\ufffd\ufffd

Excess body fat contributes to more than half of cases of Type-2 diabetes and a fifth of heart disease cases as well as certain types of cancer.\ufffd\ufffd The number of people affected by these health conditions is far greater among black, Asian and other minority ethnic groups - despite rates of obesity among these groups being similar to the white population.

]]> No publisher uatemp13 Biological Sciences Magazine:Staff Magazine:Student Medicine 2013-07-11T12:43:09Z Blog Entry Honorary Graduate, 9 July 2013 3pm - Dr Laurence Howard OBE https://www2.le.ac.uk/news/blog/2013/july/honorary-graduate-july-2013-no-1-2013-dr-laurence-howard-obe Former Sub-Dean to Leicester\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds Faculty of Medicine and Biological Sciences, appointed Her Majesty\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds Lord Lieutenant for the County of Rutland in 2003 After receiving his PhD in Neurophysiology from the University of Leicester in 1971, Laurence Howard was Lecturer and then Senior Lecturer in Physiology. In 1990, Howard was appointed as Sub-Dean to the Medical School and then of the Faculty of Medicine and Biological Sciences, before his appointment as Her Majesty\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds Lord Lieutenant for the County of Rutland in 2003.

Laurence Howard has held a number of positions in public service, including chairman of the Central Council of Magistrates' Courts Committees, the Board of Visitors at HM Prison Stocken and Leicester Magistrates\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd Association. He is, furthermore, a member of the Unified Courts Admin Board, President of Leicestershire and Rutland Headway, Leicestershire and Rutland Community Foundation and the Rutland Sinfonia, Honorary Air Commodore of 504 (County of Nottingham) Squadron, Honorary Fellow of University College Northampton, and Patron of Leicester Charity Link.

Dr Laurence Howard OBE will be presented with an honorary Doctor of Laws degree at this week\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds Graduation Ceremony on Tuesday 9 July 2013.

  • Press Release
]]> No publisher uatemp13 Biological Sciences Medical School Magazine:Staff Magazine:Student Honorary graduates 2013-07-08T14:50:00Z Blog Entry Study shows students' attitudes to academic use of social media https://www2.le.ac.uk/news/blog/2013/april/study-shows-students-attitudes-to-academic-use-of-social-media A University of Leicester-led study shows students display \ufffd\ufffd\ufffdVisitor\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd and \ufffd\ufffd\ufffdResident\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd characteristics when using social media for learning University of Leicester-led research has shown that university students behave very differently when using social media as part of their academic learning and fall into a Vistors and Residents model for online engangement.

Visitors and Residents: mapping student attitudes to academic use of social networks, published in the journal Learning, Media and Technology, was conducted by Fiona Wright, a graduate of the University\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds School of Biosciences.

For the study, all 257 undergraduate students in the University\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds School of Biological Sciences were asked to use the social media site Google+ as part of a key IT and numeracy skills module. The students were able to discuss parts of the module on the site.

They found that there were significant differences between students\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd use of social media \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd and individual participants displayed \ufffd\ufffd\ufffdVisitor\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd and \ufffd\ufffd\ufffdResident\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd characteristics.

\ufffd\ufffd\ufffdResidents\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd happily use social networking to share information about their course with their peers, in a similar way to how they might talk to friends on Facebook.

\ufffd\ufffd\ufffdVisitors\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd are much more targeted in their use of online tools \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd and will only log on to get the information they need, when they need it.

  • Press release
]]> No publisher er134 Magazine:Student Biological Sciences Magazine:Research Magazine:Staff 2013-04-29T15:35:00Z Blog Entry Do you know how your brain works? https://www2.le.ac.uk/news/blog/2013/march/do-you-know-how-your-brain-works University brain researchers to give series of talks on Wednesday, March 13 for Brain Awareness Week A University of Leicester event will showcase the latest research on how the human brain works \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd including the diseases which can affect it.

Brain experts from the University will share their findings in a series of talks about hearing loss, Huntington\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds disease, facial perception and the cognitive processes underlying reading.

The public will be able to hear from early career researchers from a range of academic disciplines including:

  • Thomas Tagoe, a PhD student in the Department of Cell Physiology and Pharmacology will speak about the hidden costs of loud music
  • Professor Ruth Luthi-Carter and Bachelor Project Students in the Department of Cell Physiology & Pharmacology will explain their work on deciphering molecular clues to better understand human neurodegenerative diseases.
  •  PhD student Joaquin Navajas Ahumada, of the Centre for Systems Neuroscience, will explain the neuroscience behind how we know that a face is a face
  • Victoria McGowan, a PhD student in the School of Psychology, will explain what eye movements can tell us about brain processes during reading

The day is being held in conjunction with the international Brain Awareness Week, which runs from March 11 to 17, and aims to increase public understanding of the benefits and progress of brain research.

Leicester's event will be held at the Frank & Katherine May Lecture Theatre, Henry Wellcome building, Lancaster Road, from 6 to 8pm on March 13 followed by a light buffet.

More information is available here. The event is free - to book a place, please email: baw2013@le.ac.uk

  •  Press Release

 

]]> No publisher uatemp13 Magazine:Staff Magazine:Research Biological Sciences Magazine:Student Cell Physiology and Pharmacology 2013-03-05T14:55:44Z Blog Entry Google Campus hosts future gene-iuses https://www2.le.ac.uk/news/blog/2012/august/google-campus-hosts-future-gene-iuses University of Leicester students aim to combat issues of recycling with synthetic biology On Friday 17th August, four members of the University\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds iGEM team attended the iGEM UK Team Meet-Up, at the Google Campus in London. Via Google+ Hangout on Air, the event was broadcast live on YouTube. The students joined 8 other teams from around the UK, including Cambridge, Edinburgh and UCL, to present their ideas.

During their slot at 1.50pm, the Leicester team shared their project which focuses on expanded polystyrene; whilst a useful product, it is a recycling nightmare, and micro-organisms that can digest it are very rare in the environment and work very slowly. To combat this major waste issue, the students aim to use a genetically engineered machine (a modified bacterium) to recycle polystyrene efficiently. By taking the active genes out of specific soil bacteria and inserting them into a more easily grown bacterium, they aim to improve the rate of degradation of polystyrene.

Aside from the team presentations, there were talks by academics, and most notably by Dr Adam Rutherford, a TV and radio presenter known for \ufffd\ufffd\ufffdThe Gene Code\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd on BBC4.

The broadcast from the UK iGEM Team Meet- Up is available to see on the NRP- UEA iGEM Team\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds YouTube page.

For more information on the project, the University of Leicester team post regular updates on their blog.

]]> No publisher uatemp13 Magazine:Staff Magazine:Research Magazine:Student Biological Sciences 2012-08-28T09:00:00Z Blog Entry
